occurrences.line_text: But that good knight would not so nigh repaire,
In slombring swownd nigh voyd of vitall spright,
From her nigh wearie waine, and in her armes
They drawing nigh, vnto their God present
The knight approching nigh, of him inquerd
And drawing nigh him said, Ah misborne Elfe,
When as this knight nigh to the Ladie drew,
Nigh to a castle builded strong and hie:
That life nigh crusht out of his panting brest:
Whose hartstrings with keene steele nigh hewen be,
Whom these sad eyes saw nigh vnto deaths dore,
Nigh as he drew, they might perceiue his head
That his frayle thighes nigh wearie and fordonne
By this the dreadfull Beast drew nigh to hand,
Approching nigh, he reared high afore
That made the Redcrosse knight nigh quake for feare,
The yielding aire, which nigh too feeble found
His nigh forwearied feeble feet did slide,
For nigh thereto the euer damned beast
Behold I see the hauen nigh at hand,
Ne durst approch him nigh, to touch, or once assay.
Whiles some more bold, to measure him nigh stand,
The knight approching nigh thus to her said,
They both nigh were, and each bad other flie:
Whom that mad man of life nigh late depriu'd,
Approching nigh, he neuer stayd to greete,
Both horse and man nigh able for to choke;
Sometimes she laught, that nigh her breth was gone,
And thereof nigh one quarter sheard away;
Atin drew nigh, to weet what it mote bee;
And vgly shapes did nigh the man dismay,
Nigh to his vtmost date he saw proceed,
Whiles his long legs nigh raught vnto the ground;
Still as the greedy knight nigh to him drew,
Nigh his wits end then woxe th'amazed knight,
On who so commeth nigh; yet nigh it drawes
On who so commeth nigh; yet nigh it drawes
Vntill they nigh vnto that Gulfe arriue,
Ne that approcheth nigh the wide descent,
That quicksand nigh with water couered;
And now they nigh approched to the sted,
Now are they come nigh to the Bowre of blis
So nigh them, minding nought, but lustfull game,
Nigh a speares length behind his crouper fell,
At last as nigh out of the wood she came,
And plaste for pleasure nigh that forrest syde:
That nigh he breathlesse grew, yet nought dismaid,
Thicke forest, was bescratcht, & both his feet nigh lame.
They were through wonder nigh of sense bereaued,
But she, as one nigh of her wits depriued,
Whom when the fearefull Damzell nigh espide,
With burning charet wheeles it nigh to smite:
Whom when as nigh approching she espyde,
Seemed to thunder, and did nigh affray
Fiercely that stranger forward came, and nigh
Yet seeing nigh him ieopardy extreme,
Where be ye now, when she is nigh defild
Her heart nigh broken was with weary toyle,
Benumbd so inly, that her wits nigh fayld,
And comming nigh, eftsoones he gan to gesse
Signe of nigh battell, or got victory;
And the fraile soule in deepe delight nigh dround:
In rags, that naked nigh she did appeare,
Which he in chace endured hath, now nigh breathlesse.
Approching nigh, eftsoones his wanton hart
By that the louely paire drew nigh to hond:
Their wooden ribs are shaken nigh a sonder;
Drew nigh, to weete the cause of their debate:
Who as they now approched nigh at hand,
Yet is as nigh his end, as he that most doth playne.
Was with the force nigh feld whilst his right foot did slyde.
He falleth nigh to ground, and scarse recouereth flight.
Yet nigh approching, he them fowle bespake,
Him weening, ere he nigh approcht to haue represt.
To stumble, that his rider nigh he cast;
And beating downe, what euer nigh him came,
And woxe nigh mad for very harts despight,
Whereto approaching nigh, they heard the sound
Besmeard with smoke that nigh his eye-sight blent;
But here my wearie teeme nigh ouer spent
But soone as th'other nigh approaching, vewed
Who[m] when they nigh approcht, they plaine descryde
And drawing nigh, when as he plaine descride
Streight into griefe, that her deare hart nigh swelt,
Approching nigh, she gins to mend her pace,
Whom when that theefe approching nigh espide,
But drawing nigh, ere he her well beheld;
He durst not nigh approch, but kept aloofe,
And euer when she nigh approcht, the Doue
Thus as they talked, loe where nigh at hand
Then came his neighbour flouds, which nigh him dwell,
And Dart, nigh chockt with sands of tinny mines.
And count my cares, when none is nigh to heare,
Nigh thirtie minutes to the Southerne lake;
That oftentimes him nigh he ouerthrew:
That with the straint his wesand nigh he brast.
Till that at length nigh to the sea they drew;
Approching nigh vnto him cheeke by cheeke,
But soone as they him nigh approching spide,
He nigh them drew to stay th'auengers forse,
Who when he nigh approcht, shee mote arede
Who as she nigh vnto them drew, the one
And touched with intire affection, nigh him drew.
Oft drew the Prince vnto his charret nigh,
Yet could the Prince not nigh vnto him goe,
This lower world nigh all to ashes brent,
All were they nigh an hundred knights of name:
Where she might sit nigh to the den alone,
So vgly creature, she was nigh dismayd,
Nigh to the place, which ye desir'd to see:
Was stretched forth, that nigh fild all the place,
Did quake to heare, and nigh asunder brast.
That him nigh choked with the deadly stinke:
That any man would nigh awhaped make.
Till nigh vnto the place at length approcht he has.
But when as nigh vnto the shore they drew,
Sith no redemption nigh she did nor heare nor see.
That with vntimely drought nigh withered was,
Who when they nigh approching, had espyde
That all the woods and rockes nigh to that way,
That I nigh rauisht with rare thoughts delight,
And from her head her lockes he nigh did teare,
Of armes, that if I yet him nigh may reach,
He her not finding, both them thus nigh dead did leaue.
As if his lungs and lites were nigh a sunder brast.
Deuising what to doe, he nigh espyde
Tho whenas he approched nigh in vew,
That from his steed him nigh he drew againe.
So nigh at hand, nor force his shield to straine,
Who euer, as he saw him nigh succeed,
And gaspe for breath, that he nigh choked was,
Stryuing in vaine that nigh his bowels brast,
Till that at length nigh tyrd with former chace,
With noise whereof the Squire now nigh aghast,
And nigh thereto a little Chappell stoode,
He woxe nigh mad with wrath and fell despight,
That all his bones in peeces nigh he brake.
But when he nigh approcht, he mote aread
Who though she were with wearinesse nigh dead,
Where none is nigh to heare, that will her rew,
And deckt it all with flowres, which they nigh hand obtayned.
Approching nigh, and murdrous knife well whet,
Vpon their neighbours, which did nigh them border,
And all his wits with doole were nigh distraught,
Tho when no more could nigh to him approch,
As Pastorella was, that nigh she swelt
She nigher drew, and saw that ioyous end:
Till that the Squire gan nigher to approch;
Bidding them nigher draw vnto the shore;
Because of trauell long, a nigher way,
And euer as he nigher to her drew,
But, as he nigher drew, he easily
But as he nigher drew, three knights he spyde,
And for their better comfort to them nigher drew.
He nigher drew, to weete what mote it be;
And through the thickest makes her nighest waies;
Now (sayd the Lady) draweth toward night,
At night doth baite his steedes the Ocean waues emong.
Vntroubled night they say giues counsell best.
For this same night. The knight was well content:
The drouping Night thus creepeth on them fast,
Great Gorgon, Prince of darknesse and dead night,
Whiles sad Night ouer him her ma[n]tle black doth spred
Lets me not sleepe, but wast the wearie night
Full enuious that night so long his roome did fill.
Their bootelesse paines, and ill succeeding night:
Couered with darknesse and misdeeming night,
Yrkesome of life, and too long lingring night.
Perceiu'd my thought, and drownd in sleepie night,
Sate in eternall night: nought could she say,
Where that old woman day and night did pray
That in their cotage small, that night she rest her may.
The day is spent, and commeth drowsie night,
Her tender brest in bitter teares all night,
All night she thinks too long, and often lookes for light.
His fearefull friends weare out the wofull night,
My chearefull day is turnd to chearelesse night,
And eke my night of death the shadow is;
Both day and night, of each degree and place,
To looken, whether it were night or day:
That night they pas in ioy and iollity,
Now whenas darkesome night had all displayd
Such restlesse passion did all night torment
Couering your foe with cloud of deadly night,
Where griesly Night, with visage deadly sad,
That dreaded Night in brightest day hath place,
So lay him in her charet, close in night concealed.
To gaze on earthly wight, that with the Night durst ride.
There auncient Night arriuing, did alight
Thou biddest me to eeke? Can Night defray
The wrath of thundring Ioue, that rules both night and day?
Now in the powre of euerlasting Night?
The false Duessa leauing noyous Night,
Of caytiue wretched thrals, that wayled night and day.
Who when returning from the drery Night,
And let eternall night so sad [sight] fro me hide.
Or that fresh bleeding wound, which day and night
As she to me deliuered all that night;
All night she spent in bidding of her bedes,
For it was warely watched night and day,
Had past the paines of hell, and long enduring night.
That day and night said his deuotion,
All night she watcht, ne once adowne would lay
And yeeld his roome to sad succeeding night,
And watch the noyous night, and wait for ioyous day.
Where it should not be quenched day nor night,
Night was far spent, and now in Ocean deepe
Disperst the shadowes of the mistie night,
And day and night her dores to all stand open wide.
But Phlegeton is sonne of Herebus and Night;
Day and night keeping wary watch and ward,
Or as the Moone cloathed with clowdy night,
And warily awaited day and night,
Hath him befalne, but cloudes of deadly night
They found the gates fast barred long ere night,
Day and night duely keeping watch and ward,
For day and night it brent, ne ceased not,
They battred day and night, and entraunce did awate.
Ne once did yield it respit day nor night,
Of feeling pleasures, with which day and night
Which afterwards did rule the night and day;
And sore annoyed, groping in that griesly night.
Dauncing and reueling both day and night,
As when faire Cynthia, in darkesome night,
And vnder the blacke vele of guilty Night,
So soone as Night had with her pallid hew
One night, when she was tost with such vnrest,
All night afflict thy naturall repose,
But there doe toyle and trauell day and night,
And darkesome night he eke could turne to day:
All night in old Tithonus frosen bed,
Couered with secret cloud of silent night,
And cursed night, that reft from him so goodly scope.
And euer hastie Night he blamed bitterlie.
Night thou foule Mother of annoyance sad,
And chase away this too long lingring night,
Thus did the Prince that wearie night outweare,
But froward fortune, and too forward Night
Into the balefull house of endlesse night,
About him day and night, which doe require,
In balefull night, where all things are forgot;
And all that night her course continewed:
They wayted, that the night was forward spent,
In one sad night consumd, and throwen downe:
That now the humid night was farforth spent,
Ne doth he suffer her, nor night, nor day,
And Night, the patronesse of loue-stealth faire,
And misty dampe of misconceiuing night,
At night, when all they went to sleepe, he vewd,
Who all the night did minde his ioyous play:
When one so oft a night did ring his matins bell.
And day and night afflicts with mortall paine,
Tho when as chearelesse Night ycouered had
From the fourth houre of night vntill the sixt;
Cald by strong charmes out of eternall night,
Like as the shining skie in summers night,
Where all that night they of their loues did treat,
I saw him sleepe with her all night his fill,
But secretly from thence that night her bore away.
The more it gauld, and grieu'd him night and day,
So as they trauelled, the drouping night
That neither day nor night from working spared,
The which in Lipari doe day and night
And all the night the dogs did barke and howle
The things that day most minds, at night doe most appeare.
He all that night, that too long night did passe.
He all that night, that too long night did passe.
When euer he this way shall passe by day or night.
Lay hid in horrour of eternall night?
But alwaies wept and wailed night and day,
To which they drew, ere night vpon them fell;
The drowzie humour of the dampish night,
Who day and night did watch and duely ward,
Where as my loue was lodged day and night:
Ne euer from the day the night descride,
But thought it all one night, that did no houres diuide.
In which his wretched loue lay day and night,
But weeping day and night, did him attend,
With fearefull shadowes of deformed night,
Together with sir Terpin all that night:
Like as the Moone in foggie winters night,
But it tormented her both day and night:
To lodge with him that night, vnles good cause empeach.
The Championesse, now seeing night at dore,
And talk't of pleasant things, the night away to weare.
There all that night remained Britomart,
I wote when ye did watch both night and day
Thus did she watch, and weare the weary night
What time the natiue Belman of the night,
Whom soone as Talus spide by glims of night,
Thus she all night wore out in watchfulnesse,
No more shall now the darkenesse of the night
Did enter in, ne would that night depart;
Vnder the wings of Isis all that night,
That thorough euill rest of this last night,
Whiles Talus watched at the dore all night.
All night likewise, they of the towne in fright,
Could sleepe all night, that in vnquiet brest
Ne day nor night did euer idly rest;
He is prouokt, and stird vp day and night
Stood open wyde to all men day and night;
Vpon Ioues iudgement seat wayt day and night,
Ne day nor night did sleepe, t'attend them on,
And foule Echidna, in the house of night;
To wander in the griesly shades of night.
Where all that night them selues they cherished,
Who with a cloud of night him couering, bore
He day and night doth ward both far and wide,
That night Sir Artegall did cause his tent
And day and night employ'd his busie paine
The Dwarfe his way did hast, and went all night;
To make abode that night he greatly was besought.
To cheare his guests, whom he had stayd that night,
Did sleepe all night through weary trauell of his quest.
But by her wounded loue did watch all night,
And all the night for bitter anguish weepe,
All night in darkenesse, duld with yron rust,
And humbly praid to let them in that night:
The proofe of battell, now in doubtfull night,
Finde fauour to be lodged there for that same night.
Whiles he him selfe all night did nought but weepe,
And there all night himselfe in anguish tost,
But day and night did vexe her carefull thought,
And faithfully did serue both day and night,
Not onely her excluded late at night,
Till towards night they came vnto a plaine,
But faire Serene all night could take no rest,
So all that night they past in great disease,
The Prince himselfe there all that night did rest,
For all that night, the whyles the Prince did rest
Effect the same, whylest all the night was spent.
Or who did wayle or watch the wearie night?
With which his locks, as blacke as pitchy night,
There by th'vncertaine glimse of starry night,
That though the night did couer her disgrace,
So all that night to him vnknowen she past.
That day nor night he suffred him to rest,
That to the folds, where sheepe at night doe seat,
And caroling her name both day and night,
Full many a night for her did sigh and grone:
By this the moystie night approching fast,
And night arriued hard at hand, began
But all the night in siluer sleepe I spend,
So there that night Sir Calidore did dwell,
Vppon this hill, and daunce there day and night:
Who in the couert of the night, that none
But darkenesse dred and daily night did houer
Where day and night she nought did but lament
Ne day nor night he suffred her to rest,
But her all night did watch, and all the day molest.
In doubtfull shadow of the darkesome night,
Who in the horror of the griesly night,
To sparke out litle beames, like starres in foggie night.
Tho when as towards darksome night it drew,
In dead of night, when all the theeues did rest
Appointed to attend her dewly day and night.
Some were of dogs, that barked day and night,
Or who shall not great Nightes children scorne,
Of nightly stelths and pillage seuerall,
To get, and nightly feare to lose his owne,
High heauen beholds sad louers nightly theeueryes.
Ne dayly food did take, ne nightly sleepe,
Mongst those twelue signes, which nightly we doe see
To keepe a nightly watch, for dread of treachery.
Of stealth and spoile, and making nightly rode
Through daily mourning, and nightly misfare:
The hoars Night-rauen, trump of dolefull drere,
And after him Owles and Night-rauens flew,
But yet that nights ensample did bewray,
Three nights in one, they say, that for her sake
Where she in darknes wastes her cursed daies & nights.
All manie nights, and manie by in place,
Spending their ioyous dayes and gladfull nights,
Nights humid curtaine from the heauens withdrew,
To thinke of your nights want, that should yee waking keepe.
To visite, after this nights perillous passe,
Which that nights fortune would for him addresse.
By muddy shore of broad seuen-mouthed Nile,
The fertile Nile, which creatures new doth frame;
Her vildly entertaines, and will or nill,
Nine monethes I seeke in vaine yet ni'll that vow vnbind.
Certes (said he) I n'ill thine offred grace,
Ill weares he armes, that nill them vse for Ladies sake.
For who nill bide the burden of distresse,
But whether willed or nilled friend or foe,
As when old father Nilus gins to swell
So after Nilus invndation,
And therewith all enwrapt the nimble thyes
His painted nimble wings, and vanisht quite away.
And through his nimble sleight did vnder him down cast.
The whiles the nimble boate so well her sped,
Taketh his nimble wings, and soone away is gone.
Which after her his nimble wings doth straine,
Her siluer buskins from her nimble thigh,
His nimble feet to her conceiued feare,
His nimble feet, as treading still on thorne:
And all her vitall powres with motion nimble,
But that he was full light and nimble on the land.
With winged feete, as nimble as the winde;
Her selfe so deckt, her nimble wings displaid,
With nimble wings of gold and purple hew;
As when a Faulcon hath with nimble flight
And nimbler handed, then his enemie,
Did beare the pendants, through their nimblesse bold:
From hand to hand, and with such nimblesse sly
She could them nimbly moue, and after fly apace.
Adieu, but nimbly ran her wonted course
Came dauncing forth, and with them nimbly led
And nimbly did him dight to guide the way
And did his yron axe so nimbly wield,
Eftsoones the Prince to him full nimbly stept,
Of the faire Nimph Rheusa wandring there.
Of Rhodope, on which the Nimphe, that bore
Or any of the Thracian Nimphes in saluage chase.
The woody Nimphs, and with that louely boy,
And them long time before, great Nimrod was,
There also was the name of Nimrod strong,
Helpe then, O holy Virgin chiefe of nine,
Nine hundred Pater nosters euery day,
And thrise nine hundred Aues she was wont to say.
Nine monethes I seeke in vaine yet ni'll that vow vnbind.
Whereof king Nine whilome built Babell towre;
Proportioned equally by seuen and nine;
Nine was the circle set in heauens place,
The warres he well remembred of king Nine,
The louing mother, that nine monethes did beare,
After she had nine moneths fulfild and gone:
Nine times he heard him come aloft ere day,
And after him old Ninus farre did pas
Then famous Niobe, before she tasted
Gainst wofull Niobes vnhappy race,
And sharpe Remorse his hart did pricke and nip,
Vnder his side him nipt, that forst to wake,
Beside them fed, and nipt the tender bloomes:
With windy Nitre and quick Sulphur fraught,
The fearefull Dwarfe:) this is no place for liuing men.
Such vgly monstrous shapes elswhere may no man reed.
His forces faile, ne can no longer fight.
That from their noyance he no where can rest,
Now needeth him no lenger labour spend,
His dwelling is, by which no liuing wight
No other noyse, nor peoples troublous cryes,
Suspect her truth: yet since no' vntruth he knew,
No foote to foe. The flashing fier flies
And with that suddein horror could no member moue.
He would no longer stay him to aduize,
For him she late endur'd; she speakes no more
Of past: true is, that true loue hath no powre
And eke th'enchaunter ioyous seemd no lesse,
He left him lying so, ne would no lenger stay.
For vnto knight there is no greater shame,
That to strange knight no better countenance allowd.
Whose need had end, but no end couetise,
And him no lesse, that any like did vse,
For of his hands he had no gouernement,
No knight, but treachour full of false despight
I no whit reck, ne you the like need to reherce.
Vpon him fell: he no where doth appeare,
That of Hippolytus was left no moniment.
Vnto his maister, he no lenger would
That of no enuious eyes he mote be spyde:
To dally thus with death, is no fit toy,
Her hoped pray, she would no lenger bide,
Mine eyes no more on vanitie shall feed,
From top to toe no place appeared bare,
No magicke arts hereof had any might,
No faith so fast (quoth she) but flesh does paire.
No false enchauntment, nor deceiptfull traine
No gate so strong, no locke so firme and fast,
No gate so strong, no locke so firme and fast,
No powre he had to stirre, nor will to rize.
He hath no powre to hurt, nor to defend;
But no man car'd to answere to his crye.
There was no barre to stop, nor foe him to empeach.
But no where could he find that wofull thrall:
Where entred in, his foot could find no flore,
Had no delight to treaten of his griefe;
Them to renew, I wote, breeds no delight:
Them list no lenger there at leasure dwell,
But all in vaine: no fort can be so strong,
But he of rope or armes has now no memoree.
Feare nought: (quoth he) no daunger now is nye?
Then do no further goe, no further stray,
Then do no further goe, no further stray,
Does faire entreat; no courting nicetie,
But she no whit did chaunge her constant mood:
Ah no, said they, but forth she may not come:
That soone in him was left no one corrupted iot.
And if that no spare cloths to giue he had,
And found no place his deadly point to rest.
He cast to suffer him no more respire,
No wonder if he wondred at the sight,
Tho when he saw no power might preuaile,
Whenas no strength, nor stroks mote him constraine
The falsest man aliue; who tries shall find no lesse.
Yet wist no creature, whence that heauenly sweet
Which I so much do vaunt, yet no where show,
But vouch antiquities, which no body can know.
Yet all these were, when no man did them know;
That from his head no place appeared to his feete.
